1.setup: Elon Musk debuts a new Tesla vehicle.
1.punchline: Instead of break and accelerator pedals, the floor of the vehicle is a treadmill. People call Musk a genius when he really just copied the Flintstones.

2.setup: The price of Bitcoin will reach an unprecedented $140,000 per coin.
2.punchline: The cost of a single Bitcoin transaction will be around $139,999.

3.setup: Linux reaches 6% market share according to browser useragent rankings.
3.punchline: Grumpy Linux users everywhere mutter something about how "market share doesn't matter."

4.setup: Disney announces plans to acquire Canonical.
4.punchline: "The Ubuntu Movie" is released to theaters starring Seth Rogen as an anthropomorphized Ubuntu logo—becomes part of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

5.punchline: No joke here, I'd just like to see them succeed.

6.setup: Kernel developers patch a half-decade-old exploit found the kernel.
6.punchline: Said exploit mysteriously appeared in a commit by an unknown developer and seems intentional. It was merged because it didn't break userspace.

7.setup: Apple announces they plan to <s>artificially brick</s> "retire" all iPhone 6-era devices, will un-brick them for $199.
7.punchline: Their customers applaud the move as 'courageous' and justify the plan as 'protecting' both consumers and the environment.

8.setup: Net Neutrality continues to make headlines as Verizon and Comcast push for greater control over what you see online.
8.punchline: Verizon starts to 'unlock' websites with lootboxes that cost $2.94 a piece. Each lootbox unlocks a single, random website.

9.setup: Microsoft pushes a Windows 10 update disabling EXEs and MSI files to all users.
9.punchline: Microsoft will hold a ransom of $9.95 in order to install software outside of the Windows Store.

10.setup: YouTube demonitization issues continue to worsen.
10.punchline: YouTube discriminates against FOSS content because advertisers are scared of the word 'free.'

11.setup: A game on Steam will be discovered to contain software that acts suspiciously like spyware.
11.punchline: Valve won't take action until it starts to hurt their bottom line. Fans of the game defend the inclusion of the spyware, SWAT people critical of the dev.

12.setup: Facebook will acquire Twitter for 1 billion dollars.
12.punchline: Suddenly, even less of your Twitter feed is relevant to your interests.

13.punchline: NSA leak reveals it's not a bug, it's a feature.

14.setup: Gardiner finds a stable release of KDenLive and doesn't upgrade it for the rest of the year.
14.punchline: This isn't so much a prediction as it is hope blinding me to reality.

15.setup: A leaked internal memo from a large tech firm outs the existence of a clandestine Silicon Valley fraternity and many of its members.
15.punchline:
Fraternity Satanic Sex Cult. called The Glass Ceiling, Members include:
  • Grand Nagus Bezos
  • Liquidator Sean Rad
  • DaiMon Kalanick

16.setup: Hardware enthusiasts get more than they bargained for as they upgrade to Nvidia's latest GPU.
16.punchline: A defect in the GPU's manufacturing process burns a permanent, faint image of what looks like a naked man into the frame buffer.

17.setup: A large bank starts to admonish against the use of their credit cards after a massive data breach. They recommend using cash instead.
17.punchline: Unfortunately, the bank refuses to let people withdraw their money and begins issuing their own cryptocurrency in its place. Their stock price soars.

18.setup: An AI makes headlines as it's trained using publicly available Facebook data.
18.punchline: After gaining sentience, the only answers it gives when asked a question are Whataboutisms, links to Alex Jones videos, or cat memes.

19.setup: Bucking the trend of privacy-invasion, a social media site makes waves as a decentralized 'forgetful' network.
19.punchline: Its main selling point: it uses blockchain technology to expire posts and make them forever unreadable. Its IPO does well since it uses 'blockchain.'

20.setup: A Russian hacker collective uses a botnet to influence American CEOs.
20.punchline: After hearing this, the CEOs start to realize that they're really just human beings in fancy suits.

21.setup: A whistle-blower at Amazon reveals that Echo devices are being used to ultrasonically map your activities.
21.punchline: This data feeds a marketing algorithm that's used to sell you more laundry detergent, among other things..

22.setup: The channel will gain 20,000+ subscribers in 2018.
22.punchline: Due to a series of videos simply titled "Clickbait, Linux, and You!"

23.setup: Apple uses their proprietary AR tech to have an 'AR hologram' Steve Jobs unveil their new product line.
23.punchline: "Oh, and one more thing..." iPhone X users who attend the event get the exclusive Steve Jobs animoji for only $4.99.

24.setup: Microsoft releases a new Windows 10 update that installs adware into existing Linux partitions.
24.punchline: This adware can break out of a VM environment and it's purpose is simple; it advertises Office 365 and OneDrive.

25.setup: A big-name AAA game is announced as coming to Linux with the port being done in house.
25.punchline: The game is Playerunknown's Battlegrounds and it performs better than the Xbox One version.

26.setup: GNOME's next release brings us 'GNOME Tautology.'
26.punchline: A native GTK app that accepts user input and repeats it back to them.

27.setup: Lunduke manages to run DOSBox on Intel's Management Engine co-processor.

28.setup: Puri.sm shows off prototypes of their Librem 5 phone and demonstrate a previously unannounced feature.
28.punchline: This feature allows the user to never turn it on and therefore is invulnerable to exploits of any kind.

freespace.punchline: Steam Direct continues to pollute the storefront with filth and bile. Valve keeps making money and don't care at all.
